Grand Theft Auto V holds the record for the fastest-selling entertainment product, generating $1bn in revenue within three days of its release on 17 September 2013.

A 76-year-old artist won a £25,000 prize for his work "Squint (19)" at Liverpool's Walker Art Gallery. The painting depicts a leper squint and is part of a series by the artist. The artist, who was shortlisted in 1991 and has made the prize longlist three other times, said the prize money will be spent on art supplies. The biennial John Moores Painting Prize, established in 1957, is one of Britain's oldest art awards, with previous winners including David Hockney and Peter Doig.

Two pro-government Turkish newspapers, Yeni Safak and Yeni Akit, had their offices attacked with no casualties reported. Four masked assailants attacked Yeni Safak, causing a fire that was quickly extinguished. Both buildings' windows were damaged by gunfire, and numerous spent bullet casings were found. The AK Party, led by President Recep Tayyip Erdogan, supports both newspapers. The attackers remain unidentified, and no group has claimed responsibility. Last September, pro-government protesters attacked another newspaper's office.

A 24-year-old player, previously under contract with the Stags, will join Marcus Bignot's team as a free transfer. He played the first half of the season on loan at Crawley, scoring three goals in 23 appearances. The ex-Burton player will officially join the team on 1st January, marking Bignot's first signing for the Mariners.

Southgate is currently the England manager, succeeding Sam Allardyce. Wenger, linked with the job, focuses on his own club contract. Southgate aims to prove his competency as England's manager in upcoming matches. Wenger supports Southgate's chance to show his quality and believes in the importance of competency over big names. Wenger also discusses contract extensions for Arsenal players Hector Bellerin and Aaron Ramsey.

A local man working at Fruehauf on Houghton Road fell from a cherry picker around 13:45 GMT on Thursday. Lincolnshire Police and the Health and Safety Executive are conducting a joint inquiry, with the company cooperating.

Transport Minister Humza Yousaf announced a new charter arrangement to resolve the long-standing dispute over seafarers' pay. The RMT union claimed some workers on board two freight boats were paid less than £4 an hour. The charter change will see contracted services return to operator Serco Northlink. Seatruck, the previous operator, argued that the national minimum wage was not applicable to the crew. Serco Northlink offered to bridge the pay gap but Seatruck declined. The new arrangements will come into force early next month, ensuring all crew members will be paid at least the minimum wage.

Ken Dickie died in hospital after an incident at Rockley Park. Jamie Mitchell, involved in the altercation, admitted to common assault and attempting to pervert the course of justice with his mother. The trial revealed a complex relationship between Mr. Dickie and Mrs. Mitchell, and the pair will be sentenced on 6 February.

Rod Temperton, a renowned songwriter, passed away at 66 in London after battling cancer. He was known for his hits with Michael Jackson, such as "Off The Wall," "Rock With You," and "Thriller," as well as songs for Heatwave and other artists. Temperton's influence stemmed from his father and his love for music. He won a Grammy Award and was nominated for two Oscars. Warner/Chappell's Jon Platt released a statement on behalf of Temperton's family, requesting privacy during this difficult time.

A team of researchers, including Swansea University's Dr. Neil Loader and Emeritus Prof. Alayne Street-Perrott, discovered ancient earthworks in Acre state, western Brazilian Amazon. The findings, possibly 2,000 years old, consist of over 450 large geometrical "geoglyphs" hidden by rainforests until modern deforestation. The team believes these sites were used sporadically for ritual gatherings, similar to the Maya pyramids or Stonehenge. The research also suggests that the Amazonian forests were not pristine ecosystems, as previously thought, and humans played a role in shaping the environment through "prehistoric supermarket" practices.

An Australian tennis player ranked 12th in the world defeated world number 29 Querrey 6-4, 6-4 in 53 minutes, progressing to the second round. The player, Kyrgios, recently won the Japan Open and is close to entering the top 10. He attributed his quiet performance to feeling tired and the challenges of traveling and sleeping during the tournament.

The passage discusses the potential benefits of the HPV vaccine in protecting against head and neck cancers. Scientists and charities advocate for expanding the vaccination program to include boys, as HPV is linked to a significant portion of global cancer cases. The Welsh government is waiting for advice from the Joint Committee on Vaccination and Immunisation before making any decisions on vaccination changes.

Jak Trueman, a 15-year-old suffering from gamma delta T-cell lymphoma, attended a school prom before passing away. He documented his life and treatment on social media, gaining support from many people. Jak's Journey page attracted over 28,000 likes and showcased his love for Rangers FC and meetings with various sports figures. After learning his cancer had spread, Jak continued to fight and urged people to donate to a fundraising page for Leukaemia & Lymphoma Research. A special football match was held to raise more money for charity.

In a close game, Egypt secured a 1-0 victory over Uganda with Abdallah El Said scoring the winning goal. Uganda was eliminated from the tournament, their first since 1978. Egypt will play Ghana for the top spot in Group D, while Ghana advances to the quarter-finals.

Lancashire County Council plans to develop a new railway station in Skelmersdale using land from the former Glenburn Sports College and Skelmersdale College. The station aims to provide two direct trains to Liverpool per hour. The decision follows a study by Network Rail and partnerships with Merseytravel and West Lancashire Borough Council. The preferred location offers potential for future expansion and good access to the town and surrounding areas.
During a Saturday search at a warehouse near Ashbourne, police discovered a complex grow house with plants. A man in his late 40s was arrested at the scene.

A 28-year-old Kurdish German woman in Hamelin suffered serious injuries after being dragged by the neck through streets. Her ex-partner, a 38-year-old man from nearby Bad Muender, later turned himself in. The victim underwent emergency surgery and was transferred to a specialist clinic. The motive for the attack remains unclear, and police are investigating while seeking witnesses.

A study by the Cass Business School and universities of Warwick and Wisconsin found that women are equally likely to ask for a pay rise as men but less likely to receive one. The research debunked the "reticent female" theory and compared full-time male and female workers, showing men were 25% more likely to get a raise when asking. The study also concluded there was no evidence for the idea that women were reluctant to ask for a salary increase due to fear of upsetting their boss or deviating from a perceived female stereotype. The research took into account various factors such as employer size, industry, parental status, and qualifications. The study was based on data from the 2013-14 Australian workplace relations survey.

Oxford City Council has been struggling to find a new burial site due to lack of suitable land within the city. Ground investigations of potential sites have been unsuccessful. Two existing cemeteries will reach capacity in 2018 and 2021. The council continues to explore options and will consider reopening family plots, using reserved plots, and interring ashes after the cemeteries are full. The last expansion of burial space occurred in 1932.

The Hebridean Celtic Festival offers an app for visitors to access online information through signs and posters. The festival features various acts and takes place in Stornoway from 19-22 July. A new augmented reality experience is provided, allowing people to enjoy the festival and interact with it from anywhere in the world.

A 10-year-old Irish-bred horse won the Cotswold Chase at Cheltenham's Festival Trials Day but later collapsed and died due to a severe pulmonary haemorrhage. The British Horseracing Authority confirmed the horse had no significant underlying health issues. The incident has raised questions about the possible connection between the horse's tendency to overheat and its death, but the report concludes it was a rare haemorrhage case.

A 15-year-old girl met David Ayrton in 2004, and now-34-year-old Davina, the defendant, denies the charge. She will be sentenced on 4 March. The judge remanded her into custody, likely at a male prison in Winchester. Ayrton, with learning difficulties, attempted suicide and has protocols in place for her detention. She admitted to raping a teenager in a garage while two others were asleep. The victim, who had only drunk a small amount of alcohol, clearly remembered the events. Ayrton disclosed the attack to a care home worker in 2014.

Serbs lost to Brazilians Marcelo Melo and Bruno Soares in Rio, with Djokovic previously losing in singles to Argentine Juan Martin del Potro. The world number one, Djokovic, had earlier suffered a defeat at Wimbledon and won a 30th Masters title in Toronto before the Olympics.

A competition with over 20 participants is happening in Carrbridge, Cairngorms, where carvers from various countries carve logs into animal and human shapes using only chainsaws. Last year's winner, Pete Bowsher, will defend his title and compete for the Claymore Trophy.

A 27-year-old rugby player, Webb, suffered a serious foot injury in September and hasn't played since. He is close to returning and aims to get fit before the Six Nations in February. Webb has renewed his national dual contract with Ospreys and the Welsh Rugby Union, turning down offers from other clubs. He wants to play for his country and is happy with his decision to stay with his home region, Ospreys.

Border agents interrupted an attempt to smuggle 26kg of MDMA from Canada to San Francisco. Two men carrying backpacks were encountered, one fired a weapon and fled, while the other was arrested. A Canadian citizen and a woman were later arrested for planning to transport the drugs. The three defendants face conspiracy, drug possession, and distribution charges. The area is known for drug and firearm smuggling.

The NSPCC's Childline service reported a significant increase in counseling children, with over 4,500 cases in the past year compared to 2,400 in 2011-12. Online abuse is believed to affect many more children. Young victims, as young as seven, have shared their experiences of being tormented and scared to go to school due to online trolls. Childline's president, Dame Esther Rantzen, urges adults, parents, and teachers to intervene to protect children from cyber-bullying. The Anti-Bullying Alliance is working with various organizations to combat the issue during Anti-Bullying Week. Childline's report highlights the need for schools to take the problem seriously and for children to seek help. Advice from young people on dealing with bullying includes standing up for themselves and asking for support.

The US chose to abstain from vetoing a UN Security Council resolution calling for an end to Israeli settlement construction, leading to tension between the US and Israel. The resolution states that settlements violate international law and hinder the two-state solution. In response, Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu took actions against the US and other countries involved in the resolution. A planned vote on authorizing new homes in settlements was postponed to avoid further straining relations with Washington ahead of US Secretary of State John Kerry's speech on the Israeli-Palestinian conflict.

The passage describes various events and celebrations surrounding Queen Elizabeth II's 90th birthday. The Queen was praised for her role as a good monarch, and a series of events were held to mark her birthday. A set of stamps was released featuring the Queen, Prince Charles, Prince William, and Prince George. The Queen attended several events, including a ceremony at Windsor's Royal Mail delivery office and a visit to Alexandra Gardens. Prime Minister David Cameron and Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn expressed their wishes for the Queen's happiness. Prince William, in a BBC interview, acknowledged the Queen as a guiding example of a good monarch and discussed his own commitment to royal duty. The passage also mentions the Queen's birthday celebrations, including a walking trail, beacon lighting, and a lunch with US President Barack Obama and First Lady Michelle Obama. Some criticized the BBC for its coverage of the events, arguing it was not fair, balanced, and proportionate.

In this League Two vs. Premier League match, the Premier League side took control with two quick goals from Diafra Sakho and Andre Ayew before halftime. Cheltenham Town performed respectably but failed to sufficiently test West Ham United's goalkeeper. West Ham United won 2-0, ending Cheltenham Town's representation in the EFL Cup.

Hospital radiographer Aidan McNicholl died in a car accident on the A5 at Cerrigydrudion. Andreas Werner, a 46-year-old from Leipzig, failed to notice a motorcyclist while turning his VW Transporter, causing the fatal crash. He pleaded guilty to causing death by careless driving and received a £1,000 fine and a two-year driving ban in the UK. The victim's family did not want Werner to go to jail, acknowledging it was a momentary lapse with no one to blame. Werner expressed remorse but offered no explanation for the crash.

Imran Khawaja, a British jihadist, attempted to return to the UK from Syria last year. He was a prominent fighter in Syria, posting videos and pictures of his activities. Khawaja was a member of Rayat al Tawheed, a group affiliated with Islamic State, which produced propaganda materials to attract supporters. He is now facing a possible life imprisonment for his role in the conflict. While his exact activities in Syria remain unclear, he was considered one of the most dangerous British jihadists to return.

Jackson, 22, scored four goals in 36 appearances for Wrexham last season, contributing to their eighth-place finish. He is Barnsley's third signing for the upcoming season. Kayden has speed, enjoys attacking defenders, and fits well with Barnsley's play style. He rejected a contract offer from Wrexham for the next season. Barnsley will play in the League One play-off final at Wembley on Sunday.

Bottles, possibly containing detergent, have been washing up on various Cornish coasts, posing a risk to wildlife. They are believed to have come from a container lost during a storm at sea. The Maritime and Coastguard Agency states there is currently no solid evidence linking the bottles to a specific container. The National Trust and Cornwall Council are monitoring the situation and advising caution.
A crash on A9 north of Berriedale in Caithness led to injuries for multiple people. The road was closed, and diversions were set up via A897. Police Scotland is investigating the incident.

Dervite, a 28-year-old French center-back, played 14 games last season helping Wanderers finish second in League One and secure promotion. He joined Bolton from Charlton in 2014 and has made 83 appearances in total. Manager Phil Parkinson praised Dervite's contribution to the team. After their promotion to the Championship, Dervite signed a new contract along with David Wheater, Gary Madine, and Jem Karacan.

Lib Dem Lord Oates accused Labour of giving false hope, while Labour's Baroness Smith claimed the Lib Dems were doing the same. Both parties initially cooperated to oppose the government on EU citizens' rights and Brexit deal approval, but later disagreed when amendments were rejected. Labour viewed Lib Dems' actions as grandstanding, while Lib Dems accused Labour of supporting a hard Brexit. The two opposition parties have a history of forming alliances on various issues, but tensions remain.

In this election, defence is not a high priority for most political parties. Philip Hammond, a former defence secretary, has stated that there are no votes in defence. Polls show defence as a low concern, behind the economy, NHS, and immigration. UK military interventions in Iraq, Afghanistan, and Libya have contributed to public fatigue and politicians' reluctance to focus on the subject. The UK has been making significant cuts to its armed forces, with the regular Army size being reduced from 102,000 to 82,000. The UK has fallen to sixth place in defence spending, with commitments to spend 2% of the nation's wealth on defence lacking. Most political parties are expected to make more cuts in defence, though UKIP and the Democratic Unionist Party plan to continue meeting the 2% goal. The UK's defence spending is projected to fall to 1.7% by the end of the decade, potentially affecting its credibility with allies like the US.

The Spanish champions defended themselves against accusations of committing offenses during the signing of Neymar. The club paid £48.6m for the Santos striker, with his parents receiving £34m. The total cost of Neymar's signing, including fees and taxes, amounts to £106.8m. Barcelona's former president, Sandro Rosell, resigned amid accusations of misappropriating funds. A judge in Spain ruled there was sufficient evidence to continue investigating the transfer. Barcelona made a voluntary tax declaration of €13.5 million to defend their reputation. Neymar has scored 10 goals in 25 appearances for Barcelona this season.

Michael Luciw, a 27-year-old passenger in a van, died in a crash caused by Albert Kenneth Newman, an older driver going the wrong way on a motorway. Luciw's family and others suggest regular driving tests for older individuals, while Age UK emphasizes the importance of allowing them to drive safely for as long as possible. The Driver and Vehicle Licensing Agency currently requires drivers over 70 to renew their licenses every three years, but does not include medical or driving tests.

The passage discusses concerns regarding the safety of implants used to treat incontinence, leading to debilitating side effects. Two patients quit the review group due to dissatisfaction with the report. Independent expert Alison Britton will examine the final report and its process. The report recommends against routine procedures for women with pelvic organ prolapse, offering various treatments and informing patients for informed choices. Reporting of adverse events should be mandatory. Despite calls for a ban, the recommendations will continue to be implemented. The UK regulatory body, Medicines and Healthcare Products Regulatory Agency, holds the power to ban procedures. The chairwoman of the independent review apologized for failing to unite panel members around the controversial final report. Over 20,000 women in Scotland have had implants, with some experiencing painful and debilitating complications, leading to more than 400 women taking legal action against health boards and manufacturers.

At 23, Muir broke McColgan's 25-year-old record by 14 seconds in a 5K race at the Emirates Arena. McColgan initially had concerns about the race's criteria and whether it met UK Athletics standards. British Athletics confirmed Muir's time would be classified as official, and McColgan believes Muir has the potential to win world medals.

Jung won in equestrian, with Sam as his horse, as Fischertakinou was a late replacement due to infection. Astier Nicolas took silver, and Phillip Dutton won bronze. William Fox-Pitt finished 12th after recovering from a coma. Fox-Pitt, a three-time Olympic medallist, had a disappointing performance in the cross-country phase. Ireland's Jonty Evans finished ninth. The passage also mentions promotional events for the Rio Olympics.

A Briton won a tennis match against Fognini 6-2, 4-6, 6-1, 7-5, securing his place in the last 16 for the 11th time. Murray will play Frenchman Benoit Paire in the fourth round. Fellow Briton Johanna Konta also advanced to the second week. The match was tense and went on for two hours and 39 minutes. Murray expressed that he didn't feel like he played his best but managed to win. Fognini had five set points to force a fifth set but Murray won five games in a row.

On 6 October 2014, a sudden death occurred at Joe's Bar in Dungiven. Paramedics and police arrived, finding people still at the bar and alcohol served past licensing hours. The judge ordered its closure for three months. Colleen O'Neill and James Thomas were charged with allowing liquor consumption outside licensing hours. The judge expressed concern over the lack of strict adherence to licensing laws and fined O'Neill £3,000 and Thomas £1,000.

Mike Nesbitt, during the launch of the party's manifesto, emphasized partnership over domination. The Ulster Unionists want the election to focus on the Renewable Heat Incentive debacle. Nesbitt's speech led to attention on his party, and he denied any regrets or mistakes. The manifesto, titled 'Real Partnership,' includes calls for action on various issues. Nesbitt views the election as a referendum on incompetence, arrogance, cronyism, and corruption.

Justice Minister Claire Sugden announced a motion to bring Northern Ireland in line with England and Wales regarding automatic pardons for abolished sexual offenses. The motion, inspired by 'Turing's Law,' will allow posthumous pardons for men convicted of these offenses and pardon applications for living men. The assembly is expected to approve the motion, providing equal treatment for gay and bisexual men in Northern Ireland.

A 23-year-old runner from Kinross achieved a new Scottish record in 1500m, finishing second behind Faith Kipyegon with a time of 4:19.12. This surpassed Yvonne Murray's 1994 record and placed her second on the British all-time list. The athlete, Laura Muir, expressed her satisfaction and excitement about her performance. She aims to secure an Olympics spot for Great Britain in Rio and continues her training while studying veterinary medicine.
The passage showcases photos from Scotland's 26 top-ranked beaches with outstanding water quality.

The passage discusses the murder of Mr. Litvinenko, a former Russian spy who defected to the UK, in 2006. Met Police barrister Richard Horwell QC believes the Russian state was likely involved in the plot, as suspects Dmitry Kovtun and Andrei Lugovoi had no personal motive to kill. They were accused of poisoning Litvinenko with radioactive substance polonium-210. The Russian state's involvement is suggested by the use of polonium in the murder. However, Horwell emphasizes that this does not necessarily mean Russian President Vladimir Putin was involved or gave the order. The two suspects have denied wrongdoing, and attempts to extradite them have failed. The inquiry was adjourned until Friday.

Steve Smith, 26, leads the one-day and Twenty20 teams as captain due to Aaron Finch's injury. David Warner, 28, is his vice-captain. Smith is highly regarded by selectors and has previously captained the side in Tests. Michael Clarke retired after Australia lost the Ashes. Warner, despite past disciplinary issues, has matured and is seen as an important senior figure in the team. Smith and Warner will lead Australia in limited-overs matches following the final Ashes Test.

A leader expressed support for LGBT+ rights, equal marriage, and extending marital rights for transgender people. He refused to directly answer if he considered homosexual sex a sin, stating that everyone is a sinner. He also clarified his past vote against the Equality Bill, emphasizing his support for equality and individual liberties.

Sanofi closed its Fawdon drug manufacturing site in 2015, resulting in 450 job losses. Accord Healthcare acquired the plant for pharmaceutical production, hoping to hire ex-Sanofi staff. The investment is expected to have a positive impact on the area, strengthening its reputation in the science and healthcare sector. Accord Healthcare is a global player with over 130 pharmaceutical products distributed to 60 countries.

Three senior council employees, Richard Ellis, Ciaran Monaghan, and Ewan Sutherland, are leaving their positions due to contract end, voluntary redundancy, and early retirement. Their departures highlight the council's struggle to retain senior staff, according to Stephen Flynn. The council's chief executive, Angela Scott, appreciates their contributions.

An English rider had a crash in this year's TT and faced mechanical issues with his Fireblade bike. Martin initially considered quitting road racing but clarified he hasn't given up on racing altogether. He didn't race at the North West 200 and won't compete in the Ulster Grand Prix. Martin had a disappointing TT experience and wants to focus on racing classics and oddball events.

The All Progressives Congress (APC) won 19 out of 28 governor posts in Nigeria's recent elections, marking a significant defeat for the Peoples Democratic Party (PDP). APC leader Muhammadu Buhari will be inaugurated as president on 29 May. The PDP lost control in key northern states and some areas affected by Boko Haram insurgency. The APC failed to win in any of Nigeria's oil-producing states, which could pose a challenge for President-elect Buhari. The elections were more peaceful than in previous years, raising hopes for the maturing of Nigeria's democracy.

The passage discusses claims against agricultural commodities trader Olam, accused by environmental lobby group Mighty of turning a blind eye to unsustainable palm oil trading practices. Olam and its main stakeholder, Singapore state-owned investment company Temasek, deny the allegations. The report highlights the issue of haze caused by slash-and-burn practices in Indonesia, where palm oil, pulp, and paper plantations are found. Olam sources 99% of its palm oil from third-party suppliers and has a strict "no burn-no peat-no deforestation" compliance policy. Mighty's report suggests that Olam may be unknowingly encouraging unsustainable practices through its secretive market for rogue palm oil companies. The palm oil industry is criticized for its negative environmental impact and labor practices.
On 27 August 2016, a restaurant started offering puppy platters due to a new law allowing dogs to dine at outdoor restaurants.

Fernando Forestieri (knee) is uncertain for the upcoming game, playing from the bench in the last two. Derby County's David Nugent (groin) might return after missing Monday's match. Midfielder Jacob Butterfield hopes for a recall, scoring a late goal against Huddersfield.

Pakistan's telecoms regulator lifted the YouTube ban due to Google launching a Pakistan-specific version. YouTube denies authorities' claims to filter content. While many young Pakistanis welcome the lifting, some activists seek transparency on the deal with Google. The Pakistan Telecommunication Authority directed all internet service providers to open access to YouTube. Google now allows the PTA to request blocking of offending material directly. The ban was imposed in 2012 over the controversial film Innocence of Muslims. Google has also launched local versions of YouTube for Nepal and Sri Lanka.

Domenico Scala, head of FIFA's Ad-Hoc Electoral Committee, is Swiss-Italian like Gianni Infantino, one of the five presidential candidates. Scala previously excused himself from the 2015 elections due to sharing nationality with a candidate, Sepp Blatter. Musa Bility, LFA boss, threatens to take the case to the Court of Arbitration for Sport if Scala doesn't withdraw by Thursday. The election to replace long-standing president Blatter will take place in 18 days. Article 7.4 of the Electoral Regulations states that any member with a conflict of interest must be replaced. However, Scala's spokesman argues that sharing nationality with a candidate doesn't result in a conflict of interest. The election will be held in FIFA's headquarters in Zurich, with 209 members voting.

Daniel Timbers and Barry Joy, both employees at Harford Attachments, died in a paint-spraying area explosion. A forensic search was conducted at the company, which manufactures buckets for diggers. The incident involved a flashover explosion, and the Health and Safety Executive is investigating.

Tunisia faced expulsion from the 2017 Africa Cup of Nations due to complaints against Caf, but apologized and was allowed to participate. Morocco entered the 2017 Nations Cup qualifying draw after the Court of Arbitration for Sport overturned a ban on their participation. Both Tunisia and Morocco are preparing for a future full of good things for Africa and their respective countries. Tunisia's participation in the 2017 Nations Cup was in doubt until a meeting with Caf president Issa Hayatou led to a resolution. Morocco's participation in the 2015 Nations Cup was disrupted due to concerns over the Ebola virus, and they were fined $50,000 after the Court of Arbitration for Sport reduced the initial fine from $1 million.

In a 95th-minute game at Etihad Stadium, Chelsea won 3-1. City players Sergio Aguero and Fernandinho were sent off, while Chelsea's Cesc Fabregas faced no further action. City manager Pep Guardiola apologized for the incident. Aguero received a four-match ban for violent conduct, while Fernandinho got a three-match ban. Both clubs have until 8 December to respond to the charge.

Wales and some parts of the UK have a significant number of people with undiagnosed cancer. A pilot scheme in Cwm Cynon and Castell-nedd focuses on identifying patients with potential cancer but no symptoms or signs. Over the past year, doctors in Denmark visited to observe their diagnostic systems. Cwm Taf Health Board believes that Wales, without obvious symptoms, has a hard time diagnosing cancer early, making it difficult to access specialized treatment. The goal is for family doctors to refer patients to diagnostic centers, and a new clinic will be established in Castell-nedd Hospital as part of a wider proof-of-concept plan. The scheme aims to see 40 patients a week, with the hope of diagnosing 35% of those with "worrying" symptoms in the Cwm Taf area. Doctors need to address the remaining patients without obvious severe symptoms. A new diagnostic center will be built in Castell-nedd Hospital as part of a wider proof-of-concept plan. The scheme aims to see 40 patients a week, with the hope of diagnosing 35% of those with "worrying" symptoms in the Cwm Taf area.

In this cricket match, England won against Pakistan with a significant lead, leveling the series. England scored 589-8 declared and 173-1 declared, resulting in their second biggest win over Pakistan in terms of runs. Joe Root was named man of the match for his performance, scoring 254 in the first innings and an unbeaten 71 in the second. Pakistan struggled, with only their captain and one other player passing 50 in the first two Tests of the four-match series. Misbah-ul-Haq expressed disappointment and hoped his team would work hard to improve.

Head coach Warren Gatland leads the British and Irish Lions in New Zealand with interim coach Rob Howley and forwards coach McBryde taking head coach responsibilities for the third time. The Welsh Rugby Union will appoint assistant coaches for the summer tour. The involvement of Welsh coaches is seen as beneficial for the national team, and the Lions' tour of New Zealand will provide a challenging experience for personal growth.

Hull City won their first league game since August 20, defeating Southampton 2-1. Charlie Austin scored a penalty for Southampton in the sixth minute, but Hull responded with goals from Robert Snodgrass and Michael Dawson. Despite Southampton's efforts to equalize, Hull's goalkeeper David Marshall and defender Dawson helped secure the win. The victory ended Hull's six-game losing streak, but they remained in the bottom three of the league standings.

A motorcyclist was killed in a crash on the B1191 at Thornton, near Woodhall Spa, at 14:15 BST. The tractor driver remained unharmed. The incident led to the closure of the B1191 in both directions between specific junctions. Lincolnshire Police requested witnesses and withheld further details about the victim.

President Ivanov canceled an investigation into abuse of power claims, aiming to end turmoil before early elections. His actions were criticized by the opposition and EU officials. Macedonia has faced issues since 2015 due to covert recordings revealing potential vote-rigging and cover-ups. The crisis involves accusations of government wiretapping and corruption, with the government denying the allegations.

After Bob Bradley's sacking, Curtis and assistant manager Paul Williams will take charge of Swansea's match against Bournemouth. The team aims to appoint a new boss soon, with Paul Clement as the first choice. Swansea wants to avoid relegation and maintain their Premier League status. The club has faced challenges since Michael Laudrup's departure in 2014 and has lost its identity. Curtis believes the current squad is capable of staying up, emphasizing the importance of staying in the league for the club and the community.

Dagenham and Redbridge needed to win to keep their slim survival hopes alive in League One, but they lost to Leyton Orient. Goals from Jamie Cureton and Clevid Dikamona gave Dagenham hope, but Armand Gnanduillet scored the winning goal for Orient. Dagenham reached the Football League in 2007 and is now relegated to the National League under manager John Still. The Daggers have the worst goal difference in League Two and have struggled in attack. Both teams are committed to improving their performance next season.

The former Reds captain, now 36, will return to his former club as a youth coach in February after retiring as a player. Klopp praised Gerrard's intentions to become a manager in the future and believes he has a bright future in football. Gerrard played for Liverpool from 1998 to 2015, won multiple titles, and retired as a player in November. He is currently working towards his Uefa A coaching license.

McManus scored early, followed by Ross Forbes increasing Morton's lead. Alloa briefly recovered with a goal by Kyle McAusland, but McManus and Denny Johnstone scored again, securing a comfortable win for the hosts.

Ofsted discovered children being taught in poor conditions in three closed illegal schools in Birmingham. Ministers plan to regulate places teaching more than 6-8 hours a week. Sir Michael Wilshaw expressed concern about potential child abuse and radicalization. Places with more than 20 hours of teaching must register as schools. Some part-time education centers may be operating as illegal schools. The government is funding a team to investigate illegal schools, and the consultation on further regulation runs until mid-January.

Lilliard Gin is based at the Born in the Borders visitor center in Jedburgh. It is the first proposed whisky distillery in the Scottish Borders since 1837. The gin production is on a smaller scale, using a small still and fitting into a cowshed. They aim to capture local flavors and convey the Borders' terroir. The gin takes its name from a legendary Borders figure, Lilliard, who fought in the Battle of Ancrum Moor in 1545. The distillery is seen as a natural companion to the Scottish Borders Brewery on the site.

In August 2013, Harry Whitlam was killed when Gary Green, drunk and over the legal driving limit, reversed his vehicle into him at Swithens Farm near Leeds. Green was sentenced to 16 months and two weeks for failing to ensure the safety of others. The incident occurred on private land, leading to prosecution under health and safety legislation instead of road traffic law.

Uruguayan striker Luis Suarez, who was suspended from all football-related activities due to biting an opponent during the 2014 World Cup, can now train and play in friendly matches. He will join Barcelona's training session and have a public presentation as a new player on Monday. Suarez can participate in all football-related activities except organized matches, which still prevent him from playing competitively. He will serve the remaining eight games of his nine-match ban in competitive international games. Suarez's lawyers argued that his initial suspension was too harsh, and an independent body, Cas, agreed that preventing him from training was excessive.

On March 18, 2014, Richard Blake-Smith and his partner Anna won a race against Vytautas Kirkliauskas and his wife Neringa Kirliauskiene from Lithuania. The race involved a 380-meter course with obstacles like haystacks, steep slopes, and water pistols. Participants didn't need to be married, and various combinations of competitors were seen. The winners, Richard and Anna, will compete at the World Championships in Finland in July.

The passage discusses the upcoming change in the car tax disc system, moving from paper to an electronic system in October 2014. This change may lead to job role modifications and the need for training on new processes. The minister assures that any job reductions will be managed through redeployment to other areas within the business, rather than through layoffs.

The EU objects to Hungary's tight controls on asylum seekers, NGOs, and a higher education law. Critics worry the education law could lead to the closure of the prestigious Central European University. Hungary's government is under pressure from European institutions to withdraw these laws. The EU should not interfere with domestic issues, and Poland has vowed to veto any move to strip Hungary of its EU voting rights. Hungary's right-wing government is facing pressure to withdraw the laws, two of which have already been passed.

The passage discusses the cast and crew of an upcoming film. The star plays Mrs. Potts, while Kevin Kline plays Maurice. Emma Watson is Belle, Dan Stevens is the Beast, and Luke Evans is Gaston. Josh Gad voices LeFou. Bill Condon directs the movie, which starts filming at Shepperton Studios in May and releases in US cinemas on 17 March 2017.

Columnist Adrian Gill, a prominent journalist and author, passed away due to cancer. He had been diagnosed with a wide range of cancers and was undergoing chemotherapy. Gill was known for his work at the Sunday Times, where he was praised for his wit, writing, and intelligence. His final column, discussing his diagnosis, was published posthumously. Throughout his career, Gill's writing often caused controversy, but he was also known for overcoming dyslexia to become a successful writer.

Rapper Amarmandakh Sukhbaatar was attacked during a performance in Ulan Bator, Mongolia. He was hit with a bottle and kicked in the face. The Russian embassy is investigating the incident but considers local reports distorted. Sukhbaatar wore a Mongolian robe with a traditional swastika, which is not considered a hate symbol in Mongolia. The attacker has not been identified, and the Russian embassy denies the suspect was arrested due to diplomatic immunity. The case is under investigation.

Plane Stupid campaigners protested against the airport's expansion plans, leading to charges of aggravated trespass and entering a restricted area. The protest occurred on the northern runway, and security review is underway. The group will appear in court on 19th August.

Nick Selman's 101 runs dominated Glamorgan's total, while Matt Taylor and Craig Miles took regular wickets in the match. Gloucestershire struggled throughout the day. Selman's century marked a return to form after a series of low scores. Glamorgan secured a consolation bonus point, and the match ended with both teams' innings evenly balanced. Michael Hogan led Glamorgan in the absence of Jacques Rudolph. Selman and Taylor shared their perspectives on the game with BBC Wales Sport and BBC Radio Bristol, respectively.

Craig Hughes, 33, from Flint, was arrested for planning to ambush police during a fake crime report. He admitted two charges in Mold Crown Court and will be sentenced next week. Hughes, drunk at the time, intended to make a false report to lure police to the Dee Estuary, where he planned to shoot them. He has a previous conviction for possessing a firearm in 2009. The Hope Line Crisis Centre offers confidential support and counseling.

In a cricket match, Yorkshire started with a 8-2 score but later posted 255-7, with Davies and Ben Foakes contributing 130 runs. Yorkshire's run-chase was hindered by Stuart Meaker's three-wicket burst. Tim Bresnan scored 68, but Yorkshire was all out for 236. They aimed to atone for their recent loss in the T20 Blast semi-finals. Surrey's Davies and Foakes played a significant role in the game, and Surrey captain Gareth Batty believed they should have scored more. Yorkshire captain Alex Lees expressed disappointment in their performance, stating they needed a top-five player to contribute more.

A 56ft trawler, 6 miles west of South Stack, experienced water inflow issues with its pump. The crew contacted coastguards at 07:00 BST. Holyhead coastguards informed them of the problem, and the RNLI lifeboat crew provided assistance by installing a new pump and towing the vessel to Holyhead.

A 24-year-old Scottish athlete, studying veterinary medicine, will miss the 2018 Commonwealth Games due to conflicting exam schedules. She finished fourth and sixth in the 1500m and 5000m at the World Athletics Championships. She plans to focus on completing her degree and aims for future Olympics, with the World Indoor Championships in March as a potential target.

Liverpool's football pundit Robbie Savage discusses the team's struggles in the current season, highlighting their lack of title challenge potential. He attributes this to the loss of key players like Luis Suarez and Daniel Sturridge, who scored 52 goals last season. The team's new strikers, Mario Balotelli, Rickie Lambert, and Fabio Borini, are not performing well, leading to a decrease in Liverpool's intensity and goal-scoring abilities. Defensive issues also persist, despite the club spending money on players like Mamadou Sakho and Dejan Lovren. Liverpool's goalkeeper, Simon Mignolet, is criticized for not being assertive enough. The team's performance against Chelsea is predicted to be challenging, as Chelsea is considered the best team in the Premier League at the moment. Despite these challenges, Liverpool's captain, Steven Gerrard, is still seen as an important player and a potential asset for the team's future.

A £45m facility in Kilmarnock will house various schools and a childcare center. East Ayrshire Council plans to name the campus after renowned writer William McIlvanney, who was passionate about education. McIlvanney, a native of Kilmarnock, was an influential writer, poet, journalist, and broadcaster. He passed away on 5 December.

A town area near a swimming pool was evacuated due to a potentially dangerous sea mine discovered from the 1940s or 1950s. Residents were advised to stay indoors and avoid going outside. The evacuation affected three streets, and wider safety measures were issued within 500m of the device. Ferry services were disrupted, and small boat owners were advised not to sail during the operation. Authorities emphasized that the evacuation was a precautionary measure and there was no immediate danger to the community. The mine's contents were uncertain, leading to its relocation to a safer place before further handling.

UK Sport has reduced funding for various sports, including archery, fencing, weightlifting, and wheelchair rugby, while cycling has had its funding cut by £4m. A total of £345m will be invested in 31 Olympic and Paralympic sports, with a target of winning 51-85 Olympic medals and 115-162 Paralympic medals in Tokyo. Badminton, which had its funding removed despite achieving a podium place in Rio, is the only sport to lose funding while achieving a medal. Judo, which also won a bronze medal, had its funding slightly increased. UK Sport aims to protect and enhance medal potential by prioritizing investments.

A six-storey four-star hotel and two assisted-living apartment blocks will replace three Victorian hotels in Bournemouth's East Cliff area. English Heritage opposes the development in the designated conservation area, while councillors support it for tourism benefits. The East Cliff Project LLP will demolish Bay View Court, The Cottonwood, and the Ocean View hotels. The site will have a 90-room hotel and 122 assisted-living apartments.

20-year-old soldier Matthew Boyd was attacked and killed by Jake Vallely during a night out in Brecon. Vallely will be sentenced on 8th December. Aaeron Evans, Vallely's friend, was cleared of manslaughter as he was not present during the attack. The attack was captured on CCTV footage. Vallely had been on a seven-hour drinking binge before the incident. The community of Brecon was shocked by the attack, and the family of Matthew Boyd expressed their grief and appreciation for the support they received.

Andrew Travers left his position as chief executive of Barnet due to a polling error where 155 stations had missing voter names. An independent investigation was launched, and Travers expressed support for the council's growth and transformation. Deputy chief executive John Hooton temporarily took over while longer-term arrangements were made. The council apologized, offered emergency proxy votes, and faced questions on fairness. Electoral registration lists were blamed for the problems, and a review would conclude by May, examining arrangements for the EU Referendum.

Gateshead won 2-1 against Wrexham. Josh Gillies scored the first goal with a free-kick, but Wrexham equalized before halftime with a fine set-piece by Sean Newton. Ryan Bowman secured the victory for Gateshead with a winning header. Both managers acknowledged their team's performance, with Gateshead's Malcolm Crosby praising their second-half improvement and Wrexham's Gary Mills expressing disappointment in the second half.
The Global AgeWatch Index 2014 assesses social and economic welfare of people aged 60+ in 96 countries. Norway ranks first, while Afghanistan is last, followed by Mozambique.

The OneWeb project aims to create a large satellite constellation with over 600 spacecraft, eventually reaching more than 2,000, to provide global broadband coverage. This requires a significant change in satellite manufacturing, moving towards high volume and low cost production. Airbus, Europe's largest space company, is involved in this venture, building satellites at a faster rate and lower cost than before. The first assembly line has been established in Toulouse, France, with two more planned in Florida. The OneWeb constellation will require the largest rocket campaign in spaceflight history, with over 20 Soyuz vehicles launching clusters of satellites. The project has already raised $1.7 billion in equity and is seeking additional financing. OneWeb aims to set new standards in debris mitigation to prevent space from becoming unusable due to increased satellite networks.

The UK government's recent spending review has placed significant pressure on public expenditure in Scotland. The Scottish government will have £390m more in spending available next year, according to the UK government. However, the Scottish government argues that cuts imposed by the UK government since 2010 have led to a 12.5% reduction in their discretionary budget by 2019-20. Mr Swinney emphasizes the importance of protecting key priorities such as schools, hospitals, and the police service in Scotland. The UK government's Scotland Office responds by highlighting the additional funding and stability of the UK economy, suggesting that the Scottish government should focus on utilizing new powers effectively.

Many people with severe disabilities face challenges when leaving their homes due to inadequate accessible toilet facilities. Changing Places toilets, designed for those who need extra assistance, are recommended for inclusion in larger buildings, but campaigners argue for their compulsory installation. Currently, there are 893 Changing Places toilets in the UK, but over a quarter of a million people require their use. The lack of these facilities can lead to feelings of isolation and stress for families and carers. Changing Places specifications have been included in building standards guidelines since 2009, but some argue for making them compulsory in newly built complexes.

A group of Italian consumer organizations filed a complaint with the European Commission against McDonald's, accusing the company of forcing franchisees to pay excessive rents and high fees. McDonald's defends its approach of sharing risks and rewards with its licensees. The Service Employees International Union and European unions support the antitrust complaint, urging the European Commission to investigate the charges. The complaint alleges that franchisees are prevented from switching to competitors due to long contracts and lease premises at above market rates, leading to poorer consumer choice and higher prices. Franchisees own and operate 73% of McDonald's restaurants in Europe, generating $9.27bn in revenues from franchised restaurants worldwide in 2014.

A social media campaign using the hashtag #prayforjosh supports 13-year-old Joshua Martin, who was diagnosed with cancer. The campaign started on Facebook and Instagram by Bangor Elim Church and has gone viral. A billboard with the phrase appeared in Holywood, funded by an anonymous donor. People worldwide have shown support for Josh and his family, helping him during his recovery.

The UK military is undergoing a shake-up involving the closure of some buildings and relocation of regiments. Brecon and Radnorshire MP Chris Davies criticizes the closure of Brecon Barracks, a historic site with a long history of military service. He plans to fight the decision and launch a petition. The closure is not expected to result in job losses, and nearby training grounds will remain unaffected. The Defense Secretary announced reorganization plans, including the creation of a specialist light infantry center at St Athan. Other closures include Cawdor Barracks and a storage depot at Sennybridge.

The passage discusses the potential impact of Brexit on the UK fishing industry. It highlights the risk of allowing EU-registered boats to fish in UK waters as part of a broader deal, as fishing regions around the UK heavily supported leaving the EU. The House of Lords European Union Committee's report warns of the industry's potential marginalization in Brexit negotiations. The EU's Common Fisheries Policy has been criticized by the industry, but the report suggests that Brexit could offer the chance to regain control over UK waters. However, the report also emphasizes the importance of continued market access and maintaining certain elements of the CFP post-Brexit. The future of the industry remains uncertain, with some arguing that Brexit will bring more opportunities than threats.

Ed Snowden, a former CIA worker, revealed himself as the source of leaks regarding the US National Security Agency's (NSA) extensive surveillance activities. The NSA has access to vast amounts of personal data, including chat logs, stored data, voice traffic, file transfers, and social networking data. The US government requested millions of phone records from Verizon, which included call duration, location, and phone numbers of both parties. The NSA also gained "backdoor" access to the servers of major tech companies like Microsoft, Yahoo, Google, Facebook, and Apple. The extent of government surveillance has raised concerns about data protection laws and individual privacy. While some governments, like the US, argue that preventing terrorism takes precedence over privacy, others, like the EU, are seeking more details on the matter. The existence of Prism, a program that allows the US government to access data from major tech companies, has raised privacy concerns for internet users worldwide.

OpenAI, a venture backed by companies like Tesla, SpaceX, PayPal, Infosys, and Amazon, aims to research AI without financial obligations, focusing on positive human impact. While some experts warn of potential threats from AI, OpenAI believes in advancing digital intelligence for the benefit of humanity. The venture plans to spend only a small portion of the $1bn pledged in the initial years.

L/Bdr Parkinson, injured in a 2006 bomb attack, carried the Olympic torch in 2012. He received thousands of Facebook friend requests but was limited to 5,000. Despite his brain injury, he retained his personality and sense of humor. He spends time in the gym, rehab, and raising money for military charities. His mother noted the phenomenal support he received, with 19,000 hits on his update and hundreds of requests to visit places with the torch. Facebook suggested he consider a page instead of a profile for managing the high friend requests.

In 2011, the US poverty rate remained at 15% with 46.2 million Americans in poverty. Real median household income decreased by 1.5%. The poverty threshold for a family of four was $23,021. Income inequality increased by 1.6% as measured by the Gini index, the first rise since 1993. The percentage of uninsured Americans fell to 15.7% from 16.3%. Poverty reached a record high in 2010 at 15.1%.

A 25-year-old cricketer moved from Somerset to the Red Rose in 2013 and signed a new deal until 2019. Short-format specialist Buttler has achieved England's three fastest ODI centuries. Cricket director and head coach Ashley Giles praised Buttler's talent and the positive impact on the team. Buttler, also playing in the Indian Premier League with Mumbai Indians, will participate in Lancashire's T20 Blast home game against Durham on Friday.

Four decommissioned Type 22 frigates are moored in Portsmouth Harbour, with bidders registering interest by 23 January. No proposals to preserve the ships have been submitted. Bids will be finalized, and viewings will take place in February and March. A decision is expected in spring. The government aims to award at least one frigate to a UK ship recycler to assess the country's recycling capacity. MP Penny Mordaunt supports preserving one frigate for a reef and diving attraction, generating tourism income. The Ministry of Defence will consider all options for the frigates to ensure the best financial return for taxpayers. Originally designed as anti-submarine ships, the Type 22 frigates evolved into powerful surface combatants with various weapons systems and excellent command and control facilities.

Since 1987, Fiji has experienced significant racial and political tensions leading to instability and international isolation. Coups and political unrest have negatively impacted the economy, particularly the tourism industry. Fiji's population is divided between indigenous Fijians and Indo-Fijians, with the latter leaving the country due to coups and agitation. The economy relies on sugar, tourism, mining, services, and manufacturing, but faces persistent trade and budget deficits. In 2014, Fiji held free elections and was reinstated as a member of the Commonwealth.

Syria is struggling to comply with the timetable to destroy its chemical weapons, missing a deadline to hand over its entire stockpile. Deputy Foreign Minister Faisal al-Mekdad blames attacks on shipments and the ongoing war for the delays. The US and other countries are urged to consider the war situation while condemning Syria's use of barrel bombs. The Syrian government denies rebel control over Aleppo's central prison, while the Syrian Observatory for Human Rights reports that rebels have seized it. The US is concerned about the UN-backed plan's progress, and Russia urges Syria to complete the transfer of chemical weapons by March.

The Booker Prize, open to all English-writing authors regardless of nationality, has Mukherjee's "The Lives of Others" as a 5/2 favorite to win. The winner will be announced in London. The shortlist includes works from Howard Jacobson, Ali Smith, Joshua Ferris, Karen Joy Fowler, and Richard Flanagan. "The Lives of Others" focuses on a family in 1960s Calcutta, while Jacobson's "J" is a futuristic love story. Ferris's "To Rise Again at a Decent Hour" explores atheism through a New York dentist's perspective. Fowler's "We Are All Completely Beside Ourselves" is the best-selling shortlisted novel, with over 55,000 copies sold. The Booker Prize, in its 46th year, is judged by a panel led by AC Grayling. The winner receives £2,500 and a specially bound edition of their book.

A man, referred to as PJS, is appealing against a court ruling that lifted a ban on him being named in the media in England and Wales. The Supreme Court will hear arguments on whether to grant an appeal and decide if it should be allowed or dismissed. An interim injunction remains in place until the hearing's conclusion. PJS argues for his right to privacy and has taken legal action against the publication of his alleged extra-marital activities. The story has spread widely, making it difficult to maintain confidentiality.

Fosse Park, located near M1 junction 21, opened in 1989 and was recently purchased for £345.5m. The new owners plan to improve parking, traffic congestion, and the appearance of units. Ernie White, leader of Blaby District Council, mentioned that the park is seen as an investment to enhance its appearance. The main focus is on addressing parking and congestion issues, as well as improving the quality of common areas and facilities.

The live-action remake of "Beauty and the Beast" faced controversy in Malaysia due to a "gay moment" in the film. Disney postponed its release for a content review, while the Malaysian Censorship Board approved it with a minor edit. Homosexual activity is illegal in the country, but the tourism minister believes banning the film is ridiculous. A new release date has not been announced, and local cinema chains are offering refunds for advanced ticket holders. The film received a "P13 parental guidance classification" and the decision to review it led to criticism from netizens.

Landlords in Southampton must obtain a House of Multiple Occupation (HMO) license for properties housing more than three unrelated people. Despite the potential for fines up to £20,000, many landlords avoid the license due to its cost of £1,000. Southampton City Council estimates 1,500 unlicensed HMOs in the area. Tenants often face concerns of eviction and poor living conditions. Nationally, mandatory HMO licensing applies to three-story houses with five or more unrelated occupants. In Southampton, Designation 1 and 2 areas have specific licensing requirements. The council has gained prosecutions against one firm and 13 individuals for non-compliance.

Acting Taoiseach Enda Kenny and Micheál Martin aim to prevent a second election. Fianna Fáil will facilitate a minority government but won't support a program for government. Water charges are a major issue. A proposal to examine Irish Water's future is being considered. Fianna Fáil wants water charges removed, while Fine Gael sees a role for them. After the election, Fine Gael had 50 seats, Fianna Fáil 44, Sinn Féin 23, and the Labour Party had seven. No party formed a majority government, and TDs failed to elect a taoiseach.

The Sorrento ship was en route to Valencia when a fire broke out, leading to evacuation via lifeboats and rescue by another ship. Three people were injured, with one reported as seriously hurt. The ship was 27km from Mallorca when the fire started on a car deck. The cause of the fire is unknown, and several ships aided in the rescue efforts. Passengers and crew were taken to Palma de Mallorca on a ferry, with psychologists providing counseling. The Sorrento may sink due to the fire damage.

The Electoral Commission reported 38 MPs identifying potential double voting, a criminal offense. Improved integration of individual electoral registers could help prevent duplicate entries. A record 46.8 million people registered to vote in the 2017 election, with a 68.7% turnout, the highest since 1997. Concerns over duplicate applications persist, with a significant proportion of applications likely to be duplicates. Clearer information on registration sites and a potential verification function could address this issue. Despite efforts to discourage duplicate registrations, the issue remains serious, and anyone with information should contact the police. Voting twice in a general election is an offence punishable by an unlimited fine.

Lawrence Phillips, a former NFL player, committed suicide at 40. In the 1990s, he was a star player at the University of Nebraska. After his NFL career, he faced legal issues, including assault convictions and prison time. He was accused of killing his former cellmate, and a judge found enough evidence to try him. Phillips had anger issues and struggled with personal demons, as noted by his college coach, Tom Osborne.

Private Derby XXX, a Swaledale ram, was promoted to the rank of lance corporal at an event celebrating eight years of the Mercian Regiment. He received this honor for good behavior and is the 30th in a line of mascot rams dating back to the mid-19th century. Lance Corporal Derby XXX joined the regiment in 2014 and has participated in various events, including Christmas light switch-ons and meetings with notable figures.

Liverpool secured a 4-3 victory in a thrilling match against Borussia Dortmund, moving a step closer to earning a place in the Champions League. The game featured intense emotions, with Liverpool overcoming a 2-0 deficit and showcasing their resilience. Manager Jurgen Klopp's inspiring leadership played a significant role in the team's comeback. The win was reminiscent of Liverpool's 2005 Champions League victory, and the team's performance highlighted the impact of Klopp's coaching on the players and fans.

Following a meeting of the EU Negotiation Joint Ministerial Committee in London, UK government representatives discussed maintaining transparency and communication with Scotland, Wales, and Northern Ireland during Brexit negotiations. Monthly meetings were proposed to share analysis and facilitate a "two-way information flow" between the devolved administrations and Westminster government. The UK government aims to work together to achieve the best deal for the whole country, while the Scottish government emphasizes the need for greater clarity and transparency on strategic intentions.

A group of 13 cloned sheep, including four identical to Dolly the sheep, are being closely monitored and studied at the University of Nottingham. Veterinary surgeon Dr. Sandra Corr examines them for signs of disease or osteoarthritis. The sheep's health is crucial to understanding the cloning process, as concerns exist about potential age-related issues. The results of the study, which could impact the future of cloning, will be published soon.

Unbeaten favorite horse races, winning against Vintage Folly. She will compete at Chantilly instead of Epsom Oaks where Enable and Coronet are top contenders. Tasleet wins the Duke of York Stakes. Shutter Speed wins Musidora Stakes, performing well in soft ground. Trainer Gosden is concerned about ground conditions for Cracksman in Dante Stakes. Shutter Speed will prepare for France's Oaks, while Enable and Coronet compete in Epsom Oaks. Gosden has a month to prepare Shutter Speed for Chantilly. Cracksman may not race in Dante Stakes due to its challenging conditions.

The currency initially fluctuated against the dollar and euro, with the "volatility index" reaching 2008 crisis levels. The pound declined against the dollar, euro, and Japanese yen. Investors are concerned about the potential impact of Brexit on trade and the UK's economy. Polls show a tight race between the Leave and Remain campaigns, leading to increased uncertainty and volatility in sterling. Asian stock markets also experienced significant falls due to Brexit concerns.

The Iron are in sixth place in the National League, close to play-off spots. They faced a tough match against Barrow, who extended their unbeaten league run to nine games. Despite losing, Braintree's losing streak reached three games. Cowley remains positive about their performance, acknowledging the challenges faced by their part-time team.

The passage discusses potential changes in Northern Ireland's planning system, where councils will take responsibility for planning decisions instead of the Planning Service. This shift raises concerns about politicians' abilities to handle these responsibilities fairly and transparently. The passage also mentions the importance of good transparency and public knowledge of political party donations to prevent potential conflicts of interest.

A one-year-old cat named Teenie was shot three times, resulting in an amputated leg, and survived. The Scottish government held a consultation on licensing air weapons, but most respondents opposed the plan. Teenie's owner urges finding the person responsible, and the Scottish SPCA supports licensing airguns for safety reasons.

Liverpool signed Benteke, their second most expensive player, on a long-term contract. He joined as their seventh summer signing after Liverpool triggered his release clause. Benteke, a Belgium international, scored 49 goals in 101 games for Aston Villa. He aims to help Liverpool win trophies and achieve great goals with the team. The club has been struggling for goals, and Benteke's addition is expected to revive their attack.

A study by Tablets for Schools found no clear evidence of academic improvement for pupils using tablet devices. The study examined 671 schools and revealed that 68% of primary and 69% of secondary schools use tablet computers. While tablet use is increasing, researchers could not establish a direct connection between tablet computers and improved results. However, head teachers reported a positive impact, and tablets may help motivate disengaged students. A separate study suggested that touch-screen computers could be beneficial for boys and poorer pupils in learning to read. Overall, the role of technology in schools is expected to grow, with tablets becoming more prevalent in education.

The exhibition "Growing Up in the City" at the Museum of Liverpool features 25 evocative photographs capturing the lives of children over 100 years. The images provide a social history of life in Liverpool and showcase changes in childhood experiences. Curated by Kay Jones, the exhibition runs until September 25th and highlights both happy and challenging aspects of growing up in the city.

Centre-back Anderson, 27, terminated his Barrow contract to join their rivals. Ex-Aldershot and Exeter player Keating, 21, is recommended to Gulls boss Kevin Nicholson and will join after international clearance. The team is four points above the relegation zone, winning only one of their last six games.

The passage discusses a new Bolivian law that permits 12-year-olds to work with parental authorization. The law aims to address the needs of Bolivia, one of the poorest countries in South America, and includes harsher punishment for violence against children. It sets a 30-year sentence for child homicide. The law was signed by Vice-President Alvaro Garcia Linera in the absence of President Evo Morales. Over 500,000 children work in Bolivia to supplement family income, with varying working conditions. The government hopes the law will help eradicate extreme poverty. The International Labour Organization allows a minimum working age of 14 for developing countries but believes Bolivia's law may breach international regulations on child labor.

A 50-year-old woman, who had fallen ill at home, searched her symptoms online and discovered they resembled women's heart attack symptoms. She took aspirin and visited a cardiologist the next day, who inserted a stent into a 99% blocked artery. The woman experienced chest pain, nausea, and fever after helping a woman in her car. She had a "widow maker" heart attack and warned others to be aware of symptoms and call 911. She had acted in various films and TV shows and hosted The Rosie Show on the Oprah Winfrey Network, but it was canceled due to low ratings.

A 16-year-old boy, Che Labastide-Wellington, was stabbed and killed at a party in Kenton, while another 16-year-old was stabbed and survived. The incident involved a fight and a later scuffle in an alleyway. A 21-year-old man, two 15-year-olds, and a 16-year-old were arrested in connection to the crime. The party was well-run with appropriate adult supervision.

A team of experts from Wales visited Denmark to study their cancer diagnosis approach. Denmark faced issues with long waiting times for patients with less obvious cancer symptoms. A new model of care was introduced with three routes: fast-track diagnosis for alarm symptoms, diagnosis centers for difficult-to-diagnose cases, and "yes-no" centers for minor symptoms. These changes have improved organization, better survival rates, and are helping Denmark catch up with European standards. Wales may learn from Denmark's experience to improve their own healthcare system.

The UK government disbanded the OFT and replaced it with Powys, who won a bidding process to handle estate agent issues. Powys will issue warnings and banning orders for dishonest or law-breaking agents. They will receive £170,000 annually for this work. Complaints will go to local trading standards, who will prosecute if necessary, but refer cases involving the Estate Agents Act to Powys. Powys hopes this new role will lead to more contracts and outside work in the future.

NHS Employers approved a plan to restructure the workforce, allowing nurses and other healthcare staff to take on additional tasks with more training. This move aims to address gaps in junior doctor rotas and the increasing number of patients for GPs. The Nuffield Trust highlighted examples of areas experimenting with this approach, emphasizing the need for more funding to ensure its success. While some support the idea of reshaping the workforce, concerns have been raised about not compromising on quality training for doctors and addressing the underlying funding issues.

Avon and Somerset Police closed Lower Bristol Road in Bath due to a crash, causing A36 road closure and disruption to commuters and bus services. Investigations are ongoing. First depot faced delays in resuming normal services, but hoped for a full service by the evening commute. The managing director expressed gratitude for public support and staff efforts.

NRW estimated that the lagoon could lead to 21% of salmon and 25% of sea trout dying annually during migration. Tidal Lagoon Power disputed these claims, stating that NRW's figures lacked a clear scientific basis. NRW defended their calculations, claiming they were based on the best available evidence. Tidal Lagoon Power's computer modeling estimated a worst-case scenario of 2% of all fish species dying. The £1.3bn Swansea tidal lagoon project is seen as a test bed for larger and more cost-effective versions along the coast. UK government ministers are considering the viability of the scheme, while Wales' Environment Secretary supports the project but seeks clarity on the UK government's position.

The DETI Minister announced a new industry-led agri-food marketing body for Northern Ireland, emphasizing the importance of the agri-food industry with nearly 100,000 jobs. The marketing body will be developed by the Agri-Food Strategy Board and aims to provide strategic leadership and direction for marketing activities. Both government and private sector organizations will benefit from this collaboration. The move is seen as a positive step towards better coordination of marketing activities, but may have implications for other organizations.

The Woodland Trust is organizing a project to plant thousands of new trees in Brackfield Wood, Faughan Valley, as part of creating four new woods across the UK. The aim is to plant millions of native UK trees to commemorate the millions of people who died during WW1. The project will plant 40,000 trees in Brackfield Wood in tribute to the 40,000 people from Ireland who lost their lives in the conflict. The public is invited to participate in this tree planting event, and the charity provides saplings for volunteers. The project aims to create a thriving wildlife habitat and a place for people to walk, relax, and reflect.

Hilary won the Theakstons Old Peculier Crime Novel of the Year Award for her emotionally exhausting and powerful book. Sara Paretsky received an outstanding contribution award for her 23-year career writing about female private investigator VI Warshawski. Both awards were presented at the start of the North Yorkshire crime writing festival. The winning novel, Someone Else's Skin, is the first in a series featuring Det Insp Marnie Rome and tackles domestic violence and honor crime.

In 2016, 24-year-old Santner broke his finger during his second game for Worcestershire county. Director of cricket Steve Rhodes expressed disappointment over Santner's injury, as it affected their chances of qualifying. Santner, a left-arm batsman and spinner, will return to the Rapids after the ICC Trophy in England. He expressed his desire to make up for lost time and contribute with both bat and ball. In August, Worcestershire signed Australian pace bowler John Hastings as their main overseas player for the 2017 season.

Barry Pring, a 47-year-old man, was killed by a speeding car while trying to hail a taxi in Kiev in 2008. His wife, Ganna Ziuzina, was initially suspected of involvement in his death due to her attempts to claim his assets. The coroner, Dr. Elizabeth Earland, recorded a verdict of unlawful killing, acknowledging the difficulty in investigating a death abroad. The case remains active but not actively pursued.

Sophie Fearns' son Charlie, from Merseyside, needs experimental T-Cell Therapy at Seattle Children's Hospital due to unavailable treatment in the UK. After a third relapse, the family was left heartbroken when a previous transplant failed. An anonymous donor has paid for Charlie's treatment, allowing the treatment to start as soon as possible.

Third-party software was used to steal intimate photos of celebrities from iCloud, leading Apple to implement a two-step verification system to prevent intrusion. This system requires an extra step after entering username and password on a new device, followed by a four-digit code sent via text or Apple's Find My iPhone app. If the code is not entered, access to iCloud is denied. A 14-character recovery key can be used to regain access if the trusted device is lost or stolen. Apple had previously offered the two-step verification system but it was not applied to iCloud backups. Elcomsoft's Phone Password Breaker was used in the hacks, but Apple's recent changes have made it ineffective. Apple plans to encourage more users to adopt two-factor authentication and stronger passwords.

Dan Groves reports that Wright may acquire 20% of a club, with details still pending. The Sun states Wright will become a club director. Billericay is currently in the eighth position in the Isthmian League Premier Division, close to play-off qualification. Wright, a former I'm A Celebrity contestant, played for various non-league clubs. Billericay was recently taken over by Glenn Tamplin, who plans to invest £10,000 weekly. The club recently signed former England international Paul Konchesky.

Mr. Ashley is required to give evidence about his workers' treatment following a BBC investigation into warehouse practices at his Derbyshire company. He has until March 21 to respond to a letter from Hartlepool MP Iain Wright, who chairs the Business, Innovation and Skills select committee. The committee plans to review low-paid workers' treatment and national minimum wage enforcement. Sports Direct has not commented on the matter, but previously committed to reviewing worker rights.

The murdered opposition politician's colleagues, led by Ilya Yashin, worked on finishing a report titled "Putin. War" focusing on Russia's involvement in the conflict in Ukraine. The report is based on facts from Russian and foreign media since the annexation of Crimea in 2014. It presents a compelling case accusing President Vladimir Putin of waging war in Ukraine for his own interests. The report reveals that Russian soldiers and equipment played a crucial role in securing major victories for pro-Russian rebels in Donetsk and Luhansk. It also provides evidence of volunteer soldiers being directed by Russian generals. The report estimates Russian spending on the conflict at 53bn roubles. Despite the opposition's efforts to raise awareness, the question remains about how many people are interested in learning the facts about Russia's involvement in eastern Ukraine.

Craig Nelson, also known as Craig Preston, a 34-year-old from Rotherham, was found dead at Woodhead Tunnels with head injuries. A post-mortem confirmed his cause of death. A 41-year-old man and a 23-year-old woman from Sheffield were arrested and remain in custody.

The passage discusses disagreements between the UK and Welsh governments regarding the drafting of the Article 50 letter. While both governments share a common goal of free trade within the single market, Carwyn Jones complains about not being consulted before the letter's publication. He criticizes the lack of respect shown to devolved administrations and expresses concern over the potential lack of funding for Wales after 2020. The UK government aims to increase decision-making power for devolved administrations, but the specific powers to be devolved remain unclear.

In the Nursery Drive and Parkhead area of Newry, two cars were damaged during an incident on Friday night. Assistant Chief Constable Stephen Martin expressed dismay over the senseless attacks on PSNI officers and the Newry community. The PSNI Newry & Mourne Facebook page mentioned that police were performing their duties when attacked and urged parents to be aware of their children's whereabouts.

Mr. Charney, founder of the company, was removed last year due to employee complaints and allegations of misuse of funds. The board does not expect him to return. Court filings reveal evidence of inappropriate emails and racially derogatory remarks. Mr. Charney violated the company's sexual harassment and anti-discrimination policy. The board believes it would be difficult for any company to hire him due to the potential risks. American Apparel recently obtained a restraining order against him, preventing negative statements about the company and attempts to remove board members.

The game will be broadcasted on BBC iPlayer and the BBC Sport website and app. The match takes place between Greece and GB, with GB seeking revenge after Greece's previous win. The game is crucial for GB's preparation for EuroBasket 2017. It is their only home game before the competition, which starts in September with a qualifying group in Istanbul, Turkey. After playing Greece, the team will participate in a four-team tournament in Poland as their last warm-up games before EuroBasket begins.
