His family and Almagor, an organization representing victims of terror in Israel, objected to his inclusion, as they considered him a victim of a rogue attack and not a terror victim. The National Insurance Institute of Israel removed Abu Khdeir's name from the memorial following his father's complaints.

A California-based YouTube user filmed his young son chasing the family cat around the garden to find a comfortable place to rest. The boy eventually used the cat's belly as a pillow, but the cat moved away after a brief moment. The boy followed the cat, repeating the process until the cat left. The video ends with the boy making up with the cat and feeding it treats.

A Philadelphia police corruption trial is ongoing, with one witness, Robert Kushner, already losing his varsity coaching job at a private academy. Kushner, a former drug dealer testifying for the federal government, revealed that undercover officers involved in the trial had stolen money and drugs from him during a 2007 arrest. Despite passing a background check when hired in 2010, Kushner has a history of criminal activity, including drug dealing, driving under the influence, and arrests. He maintains his innocence and never intended to deceive the school where he worked.

A blast at a controversial chemical plant in China's Fujian province caused a fire, injuring six people. The plant produces paraxylene, a potentially carcinogenic chemical. The explosion occurred at an oil storage facility after an oil leak, but no toxic chemical spill was reported. Firefighters controlled the blaze, and residents living nearby shared their experiences on social media. The plant has faced protests and relocation due to pollution concerns.

Jack Grealish, an Aston Villa teenager and Ireland under-21 international, wears his socks low due to superstition and plans to continue this practice. Despite some referees suggesting he should pull his socks up, Grealish remains committed to his superstition. He recently made his first Premier League start in a 3-3 draw against QPR and expressed his satisfaction with the opportunity, despite the game's outcome.

Bobbi Kristina Brown, daughter of Bobby Brown and Whitney Houston, has global and irreversible brain damage. She is no longer in a medically induced coma but remains unresponsive. Her grandmother, Cissy Houston, expressed sadness over the situation and trusts in God for a miracle. Bobbi Kristina does not respond to visitors or familiar voices and has a tracheostomy. Her condition has improved, but the quality of her life remains uncertain. She is undergoing rehabilitation, and the extent of her recovery is unknown for years to come.

Russia is close to reaching the Fed Cup final with a 2-0 lead. Anastasia Pavlyuchenkova defeated Sabine Lisicki after saving a match point, while Svetlana Kuznetsova won against Julia Goerges. Pavlyuchenkova struggled with her serve, committing 13 double faults, while Lisicki had 63 unforced errors. Russia needs one more win on Sunday to secure their first Fed Cup title since 2008.

Residents of New South Wales are bracing for more floods and damage as another storm is predicted to hit later this week. The state emergency service is still dealing with over 4,000 jobs from last week's wild weather, and they are concerned that more storms will hinder clean-up efforts. The focus is on the hard-hit Hunter region, which suffered from flooding and high winds during the previous storm. The emergency service is urging the community to prepare themselves, their homes, and their families to prevent further loss and devastation.

Model Nina Moric, who appeared in Ricky Martin's music video, denied attempting suicide after collapsing due to low blood pressure. Italian media initially reported that she tried to take her own life, but Moric clarified on Instagram that she was recovering at home after being treated in the hospital. Moric's boyfriend, Luigi Mario Favoloso, suggested she was a victim of people trying to harm her. Moric had previously been in the news for her ex-husband, Fabrizio Corona, an Italian paparazzi photographer who was jailed for blackmailing celebrities.

As Kate and William prepare for their second child, a poll shows that the British public hopes for a girl and favors the name Diana, after William's mother. Diana is the top choice with 12% of people preferring the name. Alice and Charlotte are next in popularity with 9% each. If the child is a boy, 13% want him named James, and Alexander is the second favorite. Many people hope for a girl, with 25% wanting a female baby and only 3% hoping for a younger brother for George. The poll also reveals that 68% of people support William's decision to take six weeks of paternity leave from his pilot job.

A suicide bomber attacked a group of protesters in eastern Afghanistan, killing 17 and wounding 64, including an Afghan lawmaker. The Taliban denied responsibility, and no other group has claimed the attack. The protesters were on their way to join a rally against the provincial governor.

Brazilian right-back Dani Alves is expected to leave Barcelona this summer after rejecting the club's final contract offer. He has spent seven successful years at the club, winning four Spanish titles and the Champions League twice. However, the 31-year-old could not agree on a new deal with the Catalan club and will depart the Nou Camp.

Pablo Osvaldo, a 29-year-old Argentinian footballer, urges Italian legends Andrea Pirlo and Francesco Totti to join him at Boca Juniors. Osvaldo believes they would be a good fit for the team and the fans would love to see them play at La Bombonera. He appreciates their South American style and feels they would be perfect for Boca Juniors with their abilities.

18-year-old amateur jockey Lewis Ferguson suffered a spectacular fall during a race at Wincanton, resulting in a cut nose. Despite the incident, he returned to mucking out stables and remains determined to continue riding. His fall, captured on video and viewed hundreds of thousands of times online, has made him an internet sensation. Ferguson remains positive, considering a potential career in gymnastics after racing.

The new Avengers: Age of Ultron movie premiered with fans queuing to see the star-studded cast. James Haskell, London Wasps captain, joined in on the excitement by posting a photo of himself dressed as Iron Man on Instagram. Haskell has played rugby in France, Japan, and New Zealand after leaving the Wasps in 2009 but returned to England in 2012, surpassing the 100 appearance mark for the club and becoming a significant part of the England squad with 57 caps.

The wide leg trouser is emerging as a key trend for SS15, offering an alternative to skinny jeans. It has a timeless appeal and has made previous comebacks since the 1970s. Pairing wide leg trousers with high heels and simple tops can help create a flattering look. Denim is the easiest way to achieve this trend, with brands like Gucci and Topshop offering wide leg options. Celine and Stella McCartney have also showcased dressier styles for evening wear.

The University of Michigan decided to screen the film "American Sniper" despite objections from some students who signed a petition against it. The movie, which portrays the Iraq War, was seen as negatively reflecting on the Middle East. However, a counter-petition asked for the movie to be reconsidered. The university's Vice President for Student Life later stated that the initial decision to cancel the movie was a mistake due to its commitment to freedom of expression and student choice. An alternative family-friendly film, "Paddington," was offered for those who didn't want to attend "American Sniper."

Two French tourists ignited an aerosol spray with a lighter, causing a flame to contact a quokka on Rottnest Island in Western Australia. The animal survived but was singed. The men, aged 18 and 24, were charged with animal cruelty and evicted from the island. They will appear in court on April 17. Quokkas are small marsupials found on some islands off the West Australian coast.

A 102-year-old dancer, Alice Barker, who performed in New York nightspots like the Cotton Club and Cafe Zanzibar in the 1930s and 1940s, had never seen herself dance due to lost photographs and films. With help from filmmakers, a video of early music videos was created and shown to her at her nursing home, bringing her joy as she finally got to see herself dance.

The art of washing one's own car is declining in Britain, with a third of men admitting they have never cleaned their own motor. The study by vehicle leasing firm OSV found that 31% of men have never washed their own car, while 75% of women never do. Factors contributing to this decline include increased availability of car washes, more leisure activities, and larger vehicles that are difficult to clean. Brits are most likely to wash their own cars during holidays, with certain cities and car brands having higher rates of owner-washing.

Martin Skrtel appreciates the impact Steven Gerrard has had on him since joining Liverpool in 2008. Gerrard is set to play in the FA Cup semi-final against Aston Villa, aiming to lead Liverpool to the final against Arsenal. Skrtel believes Gerrard is one of the best players in the world and a crucial part of Liverpool. Despite Gerrard's departure, Skrtel believes Liverpool has potential replacements for him.

At 75 years old, Jack Nicklaus, the greatest golfer of all time, hit an ace during the par-3 contest at Augusta National. This moment added to his storied career, and he played alongside Gary Player and Ben Crenshaw. Nicklaus' ace was the first on Augusta's hallowed turf, but it was later eclipsed by Camilo Villegas' two aces on the same day. Nicklaus is one of five men to complete the career grand slam, an achievement that Rory McIlroy could potentially achieve if he wins his third major in succession.

On Wednesday night, Kansas experienced multiple storms with reports of tornadoes. One tornado was spotted 6 miles northwest of Goddard, near Wichita, while another three were seen near Aetna. Missouri was also affected by the storms, with a potential tornado touching down in Potosi and damage reported in the area. More storms are expected in the Midwest, Mississippi River Valley, Tennessee River Valley, and near the Southern Great Lakes on Thursday. Nighttime tornadoes are considered the most deadly and dangerous, according to CNN severe weather expert Chad Myers.

An Oklahoma reserve sheriff's deputy, Robert Bates, pleaded not guilty to second-degree manslaughter after accidentally shooting a man he intended to subdue with a taser. Despite the charges, Bates was granted permission to go on a family vacation to the Bahamas. The family of the victim, Eric Harris, expressed disappointment with Bates' vacation plans, stating it sends a message of apathy. Bates' preliminary hearing is scheduled for July 2. The case involves allegations of preferential treatment for Bates due to his donations and friendship with the sheriff. Some training documents were released to prove Bates had proper law enforcement training. Two deputies involved in the arrest of Harris have been reassigned due to threats against them and their families.

Conor McGregor is preparing for a featherweight title challenge against Jose Aldo on July 11. He recently revealed a new tiger tattoo on his stomach. McGregor claims to have greater motivation for winning the title than Aldo has for defending it for the eighth time. The two have a strained relationship, with McGregor grabbing Aldo's belt during a promotional tour in Dublin.

Australian Prime Minister Tony Abbott drew criticism from anti-drinking campaigners after skolling a beer at an Australian rules function, which they claimed glorified binge drinking. Julie Robert, a cultural studies professor, argued that Abbott's actions set a problematic example and perpetuated the stereotype that heavy drinking makes one a true Australian. Health Minister Sussan Ley defended Abbott, stating that there was nothing wrong with his actions and that a healthier country would result from more people focusing on fitness.

Indiana has experienced a significant increase in HIV cases during a short-term needle exchange program approved by Governor Mike Pence. There are now 120 confirmed cases and 10 preliminary positive cases in Scott County. Health officials expect the number of cases to rise as more people are tested. The growing number of cases could put pressure on Pence to extend the 30-day needle exchange program. The Scott County outbreak is among intravenous drug users, primarily involving the use of the high-powered painkiller Opana. The future of the Scott County program and the fate of legislation allowing needle-exchange programs in other counties are uncertain.

A passionate Arsenal fan made his girlfriend take a test about the football club, resulting in her scoring 43.5 out of 50. He praised her performance and didn't break up with her. The test consisted of multiple-choice questions, tables to complete, and open-ended sections. She scored 87% but could have performed better on question 17, according to her boyfriend. The test included questions about Arsenal's history, players, and their positions. The couple's story went viral, with some praising the boyfriend's dedication and others feeling he took things too far.

A 66-year-old former DEA informant, Carlos Toro, who spent 27 years working as an undercover operative, is facing deportation after retiring. Toro, who had been promised US citizenship for his work, is now living in the US illegally. He was a key asset for the DEA, helping take down Colombian drug lord Carlos Lehder and former Panamanian dictator Manuel Noriega. The DEA refused to help him with his citizenship after he went public with his plight.

A 14-year-old girl from India was allegedly gang-raped and set herself on fire after her family told her to stay quiet about the attack. She is fighting for her life with 70% burns in Delhi's Safdarjung Hospital. The incident occurred in Kosi Kalan, Uttar Pradesh's Mathura district. The accused men have been arrested. The passage also discusses heightened sensitivity to sexual assault in India, recent attacks leading to protests, and a documentary about a previous gang rape and murder case that sparked outrage.

Manchester United manager Louis van Gaal aims to beat rivals Manchester City in a derby match at Old Trafford but will be without Robin van Persie. Van Persie is fit but not considered ready to play by van Gaal. The team trains in preparation for the game, with the goal of finishing second or third in the league to avoid a Champions League qualifying fixture. Van Gaal acknowledges City will be a tough opponent and focuses on controlling aggression during the match. He also rules out potential returns for Robin van Persie and Luke Shaw, stating they are not yet fit enough to play.

In the Barclays Premier League match at the Emirates Stadium, fans from Arsenal and Liverpool left their seats empty for the first 10 minutes as a protest against rising ticket prices. Both clubs' supporters expressed their frustration with the increasing costs of following their teams. The protest occurred after the announcement of the Premier League's £5.14 billion TV rights deal. Tickets for the sold-out Emirates Stadium started at £64, with fans hoping the empty seats would raise awareness of the struggles they face in meeting the rising costs.

A newborn baby with biliary atresia, a life-threatening liver condition, was saved through a transplant from her mother's twin sister. The infant, Star Reader, was diagnosed with biliary atresia shortly after birth in Barnsley, West Yorkshire. After an unsuccessful attempt to unblock her bile ducts, a liver transplant became necessary for survival. Star's maternal aunt, Shanell Reader, donated part of her liver, saving her niece's life. Biliary atresia affects around 1 in 16,000 babies at birth and can lead to liver failure and death if untreated. The most common treatments include the Kasai procedure and liver transplants.

This season, Chelsea players participated in Audi's football challenge. Eden Hazard and Nathan Ake won rounds one and two, while Loic Remy and Willian won the final challenge. During the challenge, Willian accidentally damaged an Audi's wing mirror with a long-range shot, but it seems no repair costs will be incurred.

A former Fortune 500 executive, Robert Dellinger, caused a highway crash that killed a Vermont couple and their unborn baby. He claimed during his sentencing that he wasn't suicidal at the time of the accident. Dellinger pleaded guilty to negligent homicide and faces 12 to 24 years in prison. He also faces a wrongful death lawsuit filed by the estate of Amanda Murphy. Dellinger's attorneys argued that he was suffering from ambien withdrawal, psychiatric drug overdose, and advanced symptoms of multiple sclerosis.

A woman from Kentucky, Lacey Spears, was convicted of second-degree murder for poisoning her five-year-old son Garnett-Paul Spears with salt. She received a 20-years to life sentence. Her ex-husband, Chris Hill, expressed his desire for her to be placed in general population in prison, hoping she would die there. Lacey Spears' lawyer plans to appeal the verdict, claiming she was innocent and blaming the hospital for negligence. The prosecution argued that her actions led to her son's tortured death.

The passage discusses concerns over two new influenza strains causing increased deaths in Europe and the US. An improved vaccination is arriving in Australia, including protection against these strains. The vaccine is delayed by a month, but experts recommend getting it due to its effectiveness. High-risk groups, such as young and old, and indigenous Australians, will receive free government-funded flu shots. The vaccination is expected to prevent more deaths than previous versions.

Caretakers of Abraham Lincoln's tomb face criticism from National Geographic magazine and budget cuts that threaten the management of the historic site. The state of Illinois is facing a financial crisis, and Governor Bruce Rauner has proposed eliminating the state historic preservation agency that manages the tomb. The tomb was described in National Geographic as having "all the historical character of an office lobby." The historic preservation agency claims the tomb has undergone significant repairs and renovations, leaving it in excellent physical condition.

The passage discusses various fashion trends from the nineties and noughties that have made a comeback or are still popular today. These trends include chokers, berry-colored lips, round sunglasses, Calvin Klein logo t-shirts, bucket hats, camouflage print, taking trends to the extreme, Ugg boots, Daisy Dukes shorts, Juicy Couture tracksuits, colored sunglasses, corsets as outfits, harem pants, and low-rise jeans. Some of these trends have been embraced by celebrities like Rihanna, Kim Kardashian, Kylie Jenner, and Selena Gomez.

The passage covers various trending stories from different parts of the world. A New York area experienced multiple rainbows, a fashion CEO captured the moment. In China, a crackdown on vice led to an end of hiring exotic dancers for wakes. A UK interviewer questioned RDJ about his private life, while the Kardashians inspired a new trend of lip plumping. Alice Barker, a 102-year-old woman, went back in time with filmmakers. A controversial prom-posal led to accusations of racism, while Ewan McGregor was cast as Lumiere in 'Beauty and the Beast'. Johnny Depp's transformation in 'Black Mass' trailer was discussed, and a military dad photobombed his son's photo.

The Miami Open is becoming synonymous with cake celebrations, as Serena Williams received a giant cake for her 700th career victory and Andy Murray for his 500th win. Williams progressed to the semi-finals after defeating Sabine Lisicki, while Simona Halep advanced by beating Sloane Stephens. Williams' hopes of facing sister Venus were dashed by Venus' loss to Carla Suarez Navarro.

Sabeen Mahmud, a Pakistani human rights activist, was killed in Karachi for her free speech. She ran a second-floor cafe in Islamabad where she hosted discussions on technology, human rights, and women's entrepreneurship. Mahmud was a prominent figurehead for humanism, love, and tolerance in Pakistan. She had received death threats in the past for her work, but continued to speak out. Her cafe, known as T2F, was a magnet for those seeking secular wisdom. Mahmud's death sparked grief and gratitude for her work on social media and email.

Mangu Ram, an 82-year-old Hindu healer, has lived as a refugee in Indian-controlled Kashmir for 70 years without citizenship rights. He and thousands of other West Pakistan refugees (WPRs) have been denied the right to own property or vote in state elections. However, they are now hopeful for change as Prime Minister Narendra Modi's Hindu nationalist party has gained power in India's only Muslim-majority state. The WPRs, who mainly originate from Punjab, have faced challenges due to a pre-independence law that grants citizenship only to those born or descended from those born in the old undivided kingdom of Kashmir. The Bharatiya Janata Party, which won a share of power in Kashmir, is expected to champion the refugees' cause.

Yoshinori Muto, a Japanese footballer, is considering joining Premier League leaders Chelsea this summer. Chelsea has reportedly made an offer of around £4 million for the player. Muto is keen on joining a club where he can play regularly and develop his potential. Real Zaragoza's former coach, Ranko Popovic, believes Muto has great potential and could be a big hit at Stamford Bridge. Chelsea's manager Jose Mourinho is aware of Muto but has not commented on the transfer.

Australia has dropped its policy of not selecting players playing overseas, leaving England to reconsider its old-fashioned approach. Stuart Lancaster should be free to pick his best players regardless of their location. Matt Giteau and Drew Mitchell's stellar performances for Toulon highlight the need for change. Steffon Armitage, Nick Abendanon, and Jonny Wilkinson are examples of players who improved after moving to France. England's coach should focus on selecting the best team for the World Cup, ensuring the players believe they have the best chance of winning. The passage emphasizes that this change is about selecting the best players, not being disloyal to clubs.

The Firechat app allows off-the-grid communication without requiring web or mobile signal. Open Garden has developed Greenstone, a small egg-shaped device that acts as a beacon or booster to enhance offline messaging in wireless mesh networks. Greenstone works with Firechat, which has been downloaded over five million times and utilizes Apple's Multipeer Connectivity Framework (MCF) and Android's Bluetooth feature. Messages are sent securely and anonymously, with the 'everyone' setting allowing messages to travel further by relaying them through multiple nodes. Greenstone aims to extend the range of offline messaging and is currently under development, working with Firechat within a 20ft range.

Burlesque performer Lillian Bustle aims to eradicate negativity surrounding the word 'fat' by embracing it as a body-positive description. During a TED Talk, she explained that she also calls herself 'short' and 'wife' as honest self-descriptors. Lillian believes the word 'fat' doesn't have to be synonymous with 'ugly' and highlighted the rise in size discrimination in the workplace. She encourages people to be exposed to body diversity, as studies show that it leads to tolerance, acceptance, and even preference for different body types. Lillian's own experience with burlesque performance has been empowering and body-positive, helping her overcome insecurities. The response to her TED Talk has been mostly positive, with many viewers appreciating her message.

Theo Walcott, an Arsenal winger, has been frequently seen sitting on the bench during games this season. He recently participated in a photoshoot with his teammates and a runway model for Paris' oldest fashion house, Lanvin, Arsenal's official tailor since 2013. Walcott hopes to make his first Arsenal start since March 14 when the team faces Hull at the KC Stadium on Monday.

A collection of props and puppets from blockbuster films like Men in Black, Batman Forever, and How the Grinch Stole Christmas, created by legendary make-up effects artist Rick Baker, will be auctioned off at the end of May. The collection, worth an estimated $746,100, will be sold at Hilton Universal City in Los Angeles and on PropStore.com. Individual items are expected to fetch over $40,000. The auction includes items from over 50 productions and spans Baker's 30-year career, which includes work on films like American Werewolf in London, Planet of the Apes, Batman & Robin, Hellboy, and Mighty Joe Young.

A seven-year-old British boy, Carwyn Scott-Howell, died while skiing with his family in the French Alps. He got separated from his mother and entered dense woodland, falling over a 164ft drop. His family described him as daring, outgoing, and determined, with a handsome smile that lit up any room. Carwyn was an experienced skier and snowboarder, and his family had spent a happy ski holiday together before the tragedy. His mother desperately searched for him, but his body was eventually found by police following footprints in the snow. Carwyn's family and friends mourn his loss, with his school describing him as a lively, likeable pupil who will be greatly missed.

A 15-year-old girl, Laura Scurr, became obsessed with her weight and developed anorexia, leading to a dramatic weight loss and eventual collapse at home. She was hospitalized and placed on a heart machine. Laura spoke out about the pressures on teenagers to be a size zero, revealing her own struggles with weight and body image. She eventually began her recovery with support from eating disorder organizations. Anorexia is a serious mental health condition that often develops in people with concerns about their body shape or weight. It is crucial to seek help and support for those suffering from eating disorders.

Liverpool players, including Raheem Sterling, unveiled the club's new home kit designed by New Balance at Anfield. The kit launch came amidst Sterling's contract negotiations, but Liverpool supporters expressed their desire for him to remain at the club. The new kit features a gingham design and is part of a £300 million four-year deal between New Balance and Liverpool. The players, including Sterling, expressed their commitment to the club and their desire for success during the upcoming season.

The largest single high-definition map of dark matter has been produced, showing clumps of mystery particles across 0.4% of the sky. The goal is to eventually map 12.5% of the sky over five years. The map was created using data from the Dark Energy Camera, a 570-megapixel imaging device. Dark matter, which makes up at least 80% of the matter in the known universe, is invisible and interacts only through gravity. The project aims to study the dynamics of galaxies and the movement of stars to understand the formation of galaxies. The Dark Energy Survey will create a 3D map of dark matter and dark energy, allowing scientists to better test current cosmological theories by comparing the amounts of dark and visible matter.

Manchester United have made an official approach for PSV Eindhoven's star player Memphis Depay, a 21-year-old Dutch international. United manager Louis van Gaal is keen to sign Depay, who he previously named in his 23-man World Cup squad. Depay has scored 20 goals in 26 league games for PSV this season and is valued highly, with competition from other top European clubs.

Chelsea took a commanding 3-1 lead against Manchester City's young side, with key players Tammy Abraham and Dominic Solanke scoring. The match saw strong performances from Chelsea's defense and midfield, while Manchester City struggled to find their rhythm. Both teams showcased promising young talent, with several players standing out on each side.

Marco Rubio, a presidential candidate, believes people are born with a sexual preference. He supports state legislators deciding on gay marriage, not considering it a constitutional right. Rubio stated that marriage should be between one man and one woman, and people should petition their state legislature for different definitions. He doesn't believe sexual preference is a choice for most people and would attend a same-sex wedding of a family member or staffer, even if he disagreed with the decision. Rubio is a Catholic and believes divorce is wrong, but would still love someone if they were divorced. He has received monetary commitments exceeding the estimated $51 million needed for the presidential primary season.

Pablo Mandado and Ilze Zebolde are a couple embarking on a global cycling journey with no plans, agenda, or specific cause. After quitting their restaurant jobs in Manchester, they are traveling as cheaply as possible, living on less than three euros each per day. They rely on free accommodation, such as camping and using hosting websites, and their legs provide transportation. Their primary expense is food, with a daily budget of 2.74 euros each. They have covered 7,000 miles in 356 days, passing through 16 countries. Their journey began in London and has taken them through France, Spain, Italy, Slovenia, and Turkey, among other countries. They plan to continue their journey across Asia, the Pacific, and eventually cycle the entire length of the American continent.

A Texas couple discovered racist slurs on their wedding photo booth pictures in 2012 and hired attorney Cathy Hale to sue James Evans, the owner of Premier Photos. The couple claims that Evans provided a photo booth with offensive captions. Evans denies the allegations and the case is set for trial in July, with the couple seeking an apology rather than monetary compensation.

Mike Brown, England full-back, admitted to adopting a cautious approach in recovering from his recent concussion. He remains uncertain about his return to action for club side Harlequins. Meanwhile, Northampton wing George North has been advised not to play this season after suffering four quick-fire concussions, while Johnny Sexton was stood down for 12 weeks earlier. Brown emphasized the importance of being cautious and not rushing back to avoid extended breaks like other players. He also credited increased awareness of concussion symptoms from online modules for helping him make informed decisions about his health.

Smartphone use may contribute to a decrease in the frequency of couples having sex each month, according to a leading expert. Research shows that the frequency of sex among Britons has declined since the internet's emergence. A typical heterosexual couple now has sex three times a month, compared to four times in 2000 and five times in 1990. Factors contributing to this decline include increased time spent on personal devices, busier lives, and blurred boundaries between work and home life.

Tibetan Mastiffs, once highly valued in China, have experienced a dramatic decline in popularity. Weighing up to 80 kg, these dogs were once prized possessions, commanding prices of up to £1.2 million each. However, due to China's anti-corruption crackdown and recent bans on owning dogs over 50 kg in several cities, their value has plummeted. Some are now being sent to slaughterhouses for cheap hotpot meat. The breed's quality has also been compromised by cross-breeding and unscrupulous breeders. As a result, many poor-quality dogs are left unsold, and some are even stolen and sold to slaughterhouses.

In Paris, every woman surveyed reported experiencing some form of sexual harassment on public transport. Half of them were assaulted before turning 18. The survey led to calls for a campaign to combat sexist or threatening behavior on buses and trains. The problem affects women's freedom, often forcing them to alter their daily lives to avoid confrontation. The French Women's Rights Ministry received a report highlighting the issue, and the High Council for Gender Equality aims to ensure women can move freely and safely in public spaces.

A competition called #everydayfix by Leeds-based Direct Line aims to solve common problems through prototype products. The top ten everyday emergencies include not being able to sleep, losing keys, and running out of phone battery. Three shortlisted products are Snooze, a smart alarm clock that silences notifications for better sleep; Forget Me Lock, a device that reassures you of your locked front door; and Nipper, the world's smallest mobile phone charger. The winning product will be funded through a Kickstarter campaign.

A police crime commissioner is under investigation after awarding over half a million pounds of taxpayers' money to a charity she co-runs with the force's chief. Vera Baird, the police and crime commissioner for Northumbria, faces a Ministry of Justice probe as critics accuse her and Sue Sim, Northumbria's chief constable, of creating a conflict of interest. The pair are directors of Victims First Northumbria, a charity supporting crime victims in the area.

Three people have been sent to prison and two more are awaiting sentencing for their roles in a brutal assault on a 53-year-old man. The victim, Greg Valecce, was beaten, tied to a chair, and given offensive tattoos. Corry 'Corey' Campbell, 21, was the ringleader of the gang, known as the 'tattoo terrorists'. They believed Valecce had hurt Campbell's cat. The assault took place in a basement where Valecce was staying. Campbell, his girlfriend Sandra Ng, and friend Carl Halin were sentenced for their roles in the abuse. Valecce suffered multiple injuries and was able to escape and contact the police. The group was charged with aggravated assault, conspiracy, and false imprisonment.
